div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: IS THE CLIMATE OF EGYPT CHANGING?
div.p: THis is a question that one often hears at the present time. It is sometimes said that rain was formerly unknown in Egypt, whilst now it is a yearly occurence. Various theories are advanced to account for this alleged change, the most popular of which are the opening out of the Suez Canal and the great extension of works of irrigation during the last twenty years. In his recent work, "The Physiography of the Nile and its Basin," Capt. H. G. Lyons, F.R.G.S., Director General of the Survey Department, speaking of the Nile Valley from Assouan to Cairo, says, "A few rainstorms occur every winter, but they are usually very local in their effect. On the eastern side the much larger area and the steeper slopes, together with the greater frequency of rain near the Red Sea hills, make the winter rainfall a more important factor. In about every second year one or other of the large wadis comes down in flood, somemtimes so suddenly as to carry away camels and sheep which may be grazing in the valleys, and pours a large volume of water into the Nile. These seils (or rain floods) are less rare than is usually supposed, and the dry, arid appearance of the desert, together with the rareness of rain, cause the effect of such storms as do occur to be understimated." A reference to the Memoirs of the learned staff brought to Egypt by Napoleon at the end of the eighteenth century shows that as the climate was then so it is now. "But at least," says the tourist, "no rain falls in Upper Egypt." It is pardonable therefore on looking out from the hotel verandah at Assouan and seeing the clouds pouring forth their supply that the visitor should think that the season of his visit is an exceptional year. With regad to the recent cold weather, although perhaps more severe than usual, visitors always seem surprised on arriving in Egypt to find that their preconceived ideas as to the climate were wrong. Occasionally it is so cold at to make people regret leaving their warm winter clothing at home, and the wearing of furs, however absurd it may sound to people previous to leaving England for Egypt is quite common during the winter months. As a matter of fact, unless people are warmly clad during the evening after sunset in Egypt at the present time they are very liable to many of the ills incidental to exposure to cold. In this respect it is often cruel to see the foolish fashion which prevails of dressing children in short socks, thus exposing the lower limbs and consequently reducing their resisting powers. Although Egypt has one of the best Winter climates in the world yet there are timesalbeit few and far between- when one requires to be even as careful as in countries further North.

div.head: SUDAN AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: RAILWAY CONNECTION.
Mr. Barois is leaving Egypt on the 10th proxo., having been nominated by his Government as techincal and financial delegate on the French Mission to Ethiopia in connection with the railways.

A most encouraging feature of the report of the International Ethiopian Railway Trust, which has just been published for the two years to September 20th, 1907, is the statement that the expectations of the board as to an arrangement ultimately being arrived at between Powers chiefly interested, recognising and guaranteeing the independence of Abyssinia, and harmonising their commercial policies in regard to Abyssinian railways, have been entirely fulfilled.

In virture of certain clauses of the Concession of 1894 the right of extending the Imperial Ethiopian Railway Company's line from Addis Adeba westward towards the Nile is held, as is the second section to Addis Abeba, by that company, but according to the treaty, the extension towards the Nile will apparently have to be carried out under the auspices of Great Britain; while the other lines foreshadowed from the Red Sea and Indian Ocean would appear likewise, in accordance with Article 3 of the Concessions, to come within the rights granted to the concessionaires.

div.head: Council of Ministers
div.p: The next Council of Ministers will be held on Monday next at Abdeen Palace, instead of today.

div.head: All Saints' Cairo
div.p: The Rt. Rev. Pophem Blyth, Bishop in Jerusalem, will preach at All Saints', Cairo, on Sunday at the morning service.

div.head: The Latest Issues
div.p: The most recent issues have all been satisfactorily covered many times over. The Ghezireh Mansions, Limited, was well over subscribed. The subscription to the Banque d'Escompte et de Reports was covered sixteen times over, and Levico, Limited, ten times over.

div.head: Greek Philharmonic Society
div.p: The celebrated Athens Philharmonic Society, which is passing through Alexandria, will give a series of performances at the El Dorado for nine days, commencing today, from 5:30 to 8 p.m. and from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m.

div.head: The Weather.
div.p: The S.S. Osmanieh, which arrived at Alexandria this morning from Constantinople and the Piraeus, reports having experienced terrific weather between here and Piraeus. A very heavy gale is raging, and shipping has been seriously interferred with, though the Osmanieh weathered the storm admirably.

div.head: The Savoy Palace Hotel
div.p: We are requested by the manager of this Alexandrian hotel, which is to be officially opened to-day, to state that the invitation list to the ceremony has been made as comprehensive as possible, but if there are any omissions it is to be hoped that it will not be considered that they were in any way intentional.

div.head: Amie de la Jeune Fille.
div.p: A sale will be held on the 16th March at the Grand Continental Hotel between 3 and 6, in aid of the funds of the Cairo branch of the Amie de la Jeune Fille, which is under the patronage of Lady Cromer. In view of the excellent work this society does not only in Cairo but all the world over, we are confident that the committee's appeal will meet with a hearty response.

div.head: Wagner's Music.
div.p: An interesting lecture is to be given at Connaught House, Cairo, on Monday next at 5 p.m., when Rev. W.T. Gairdeer will discourse on "Wagner's Music." Added interest is given to the lecture by the fact that there will be vocal, piano, and violin illustrations of the speaker's subject. The lecture will be open to ladies and gentlemen, and reserved seats may be had at P.T. 10.

div.head: Windsor Hotel.
div.p: Several visitors at the Windsor Hotel, acting on a spontaneous suggestion, arranged and gave a very enjoyable variety entertainment last night. It opened with a symphony by Gungl', and the other items included a remarkable spiritualistic performance by a Baron who is staying there; a "Rhapsodie" for cello by the soloist to General Mashasha; an American gig for bajo; a clever acrobatic performance by a local celebrity; and a weird Turkish operatic air "Zah Zable."

div.head: Concert.
div.p: The Marquis Francesco Filiasi and Maestro Vincenzo Cantani, who gave so successful a performance at Cairo the other day, will give a concert at 9 30 p.m. tomorrow at the new Savoy Palace Hotel. The programme consists of a Sunatra (Opus 45) for piano an violin; Chopin's "Preludes," "Nocturne" and "Polonaise;" and "Adagio by M x Bruch;" a "Scherzo" and other compositions by the Marquis himself, and a fantaisie on "Faust" by Wieniawsky for violin.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POST OFFICE
POSTAGE OF LOTTERY TICKETS.
div.p: Complaints are again appearing in the London Press in reference to the way the services of the Egyptian Post Office are being abused owing to the introduction of penny postage between Egypt and England in order to flood the country with lottery circulars emanating from a Hungarian lottery syndicate, which are depatched in vast quantities from Alexandria.

Complaints, to which the above telegram alludes, appeared first some months ago, and a question was asked in the House of Commons on the subject. The Egyptian postal authorities are, however, quite powerless to move in the matter, and there is no way of checking the despatch of lottery tickets from Alexandria to England. As soon as the penny post was introduced between this country and England the promoters of European lotteries took advantage of it, for by this means they can send their circulars to England in a sealed or closed letter for the same price as they can despatch them from their own countries in open envelopes. As the latter are liable to be confiscated by the postal authorities on their arrival in England, while closed letters cannot be tampered with, the advantages of Egypt for their business are obvious. Shortly after the lowering of the postal rates an enormous traffic developed, and just after penny postage had been introduced no less than 200,000 lottery circulars were sent through the Alexandria Post Office to England in a single day. It is not known whether these lottery circulars are printed here or imported in bulk from Europe. It is very lucrative for the Egyptian Post Office and there is every likelihood that this source of revenue will continue, for it is difficult to devise any means of preventing the despatch of closed envelopes to England.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL CHARGES.
div.p: AUSTRALIAN PREMIER"S LETTER.

In Thursday's issue we gave a summary of the discussion between the Foreign Office and the Federal Prime Minister of Australia on the subject of the Suez Canal charges. Australian traders are much incensed with the Foreign Office by reason of the attitude the department has taken up with regard to the question of a reduction in the Suez Canal charges on Australian trade. The correspondence between Mr. Deskin and Lord Elgin on the subject has recently been published in Australia. In making his demand, the Australian Prime Minister said:- "Seeing that the canal dues enable shareholders to receive a dividend of 28 per cent.. the time has arrived for their reconsideration and perhaps for a substantial reduction."

The reply of Lord Elgin encloses a long examination of Mr. Deskin's demand by the three British directors of the Canal Company, and intimates that their statement is approved by the Treasury and the Board of Trade. The Colonial Secretary adds that the two Departments named "do not think that anything would be gained by an attempt to pursue that object (reduced charges for vessels coming to or from Australia) without due regard to the interest of those who have a purely financial concern in the affairs of the Suez Canal."
The point made by the canal directors can be given in very few words:-
"We submit that any further reductions of the tariff would practically amount to a subsidy to ships using the canal at the cost, to a great extent, of pecuniary loss to His Majesty's Government."

The directors deny that the dividend of 28 per cent. on the 500 francs share is exorbitant, for "owing to the large increase in the market value of the shares, the return to the purchasers for some years past has ranged between 3 and 4 per cent." Elsewhere in the letter they say:- "That the inter Empire trade would be beneficially affected [by the proposed reductions] is no doubt a very valid reason for both the home and colonial Governments to press for further reductions; but these would obviously have a precisely opposite effect upon the foreign rivals of our maritime commerce through the casual, and it would be futile to urge this argument upon our Continental colleagues."

div.head: MINING IN EGYPT.
div.p: A circular issued by the Egyptian Options, Limited, states that in October, 1905, the company obtained a concession from the Egyptian Government of two areas containing approximately 10,000 square miles, and known as the Eigat and Jebel Eiba Concessions, which they hold jointly with the London Johannesburg and Cairo Trustees Limited. The directors have received a report made by Mr. Francis Merton, the manager of the prospecting party, which is now circulated. The news of the discovery was made by Mr. Merton and his party was conveyed to the shareholders on the 6th, April, 1906. Since the date the work of development has been actively prospected, with the result that no less than seventy-five different places have been discovered along the strike of the reefs disclosing ancient working, and exposing reefs showing visible gold. Twelve of these old workings have been cleared cut with most satisfacory results and in the opinion of the miners who have been sent to the property from the Great Boulder Mine in Western Australia, it is the biggest surface show they have ever seen, and there is enough stone in sight to at once start a 100 head mill. The directors have put themselves in communication with an importnat group with a view to the formation of a company with a sufficient working captial to successfully work the property.

div.head: BRITISH FORCES IN EGYPT.
NEW COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF.
div.p: It has been decided to appoint a purely military Commander-in-Chief of the British forces in the Mediterranean and Egypt, with no civil or governmental duties. He will be stationed at Malta.
(Reuter)

div.head: ANTI TUBERCULOSIS LEAGUE.
div.p: MEETING OF LOCAL LADIES.

An interesting meeting was held yesterday afternoon in the council chamber of the Alexandria Municipality. Dr. Schiess Pasha, president of the Anti-Tuberculosis League, had convoked a number of ladies with the object of forming from among them a committee for the purpose of organising some form of entertainment whereby the funds of the league would be benefited. Schiess Pasha's invitation was largely responded to and the council chamber presented an unusual, but at the same time charming appearance, with the members of the fair sex seated round the City Fathers' large table. Among those present were Baroness Jazques de Menasce, Mesdames Chataway, Aicard, Vallasopoulos, Joannides, Beneducci, Norra, Mettioli, Rubino, Nahman, Tilche, Luzzette, Alderson, etc.

Dr. Schiess Bey opened the proceedings with an appropriate speech in which he said that he felt sure he had only to make an appeal in behalf of the deserving instituion in questsion for it to have an immediate and hearty reponse from the ladies who had gathered there that afternoon. He spoke of the excellent work which the league had done, but said that there was a need for the extension of its usefulness. They could help by forming a committee among them whose object would be to devise some means of increasing the league's revenue. A ballot was then held, with the result that the following ladies were selected to sit on the committee; Mesdanes Isaac de Joseph Aghion, Charles Bacos, J. Bouan, Lady Blomfield, Countess Caprara, P. Chataway, P. Girard, E.B. Gould, Joannides, Kingham, Emin Karam, H. Lindemann, Lugzatto, G. Mettioli, Baroness Jacques Fel x de Menasce, A. Morrison, F. Planta, Michel Salvago, Constantin Sinadino, Christian Sinadino, Jacques Suares, Joseph Suares, Alexander Sursock, A. Torells, C. Wunderlich, Emmanue Zervudachi, Countess Alex de Zogheb.
After the business of the meeting, the ladies were entertained at tes, which was laid out very tastefully on side tables.

Liberal contributions to the funds of the league were made at the meeting, the following ladies contibuting the sums mentioned against the names; Mme. Joannides, £200; Mme Emio Karam £40; Mme E. Benachi, £20; Mrs. G.B. Alderson, £0; Mme Bouan, £8; Mme Mettioli, £5; Mme G. Campos, £12; Mme Papadopoulos, £2.

Before closing our report of the proceedings we must pay a tribute to the seal and energy displayed in the cause of this charity by Schiess Pasha, the president, and Norsa Bey, the secretary, who have been untiring in their efforts to make it a success.
The first meeting of the newly-formed general committee will take place on the 28th inst. in order to elect a president and an executive committee.

div.head: IMPORT OF ANTIQUITIES.
div.p: To import antiquities to Egypt is as much a work of supererogation as to carry coals to Newcastle. A highly enterprising Greek, however, has just embarked on this new line of business, but his career has been promptly checked by the Hellenic consular authorities at Alexandria. This person, whose name is A. Pissarakis, a short time ago brought a valuable marble statue of the best epoch of Greek art to Alexandria, which he had stolen from Greece. Here he offered it to some well known Greek residents, but they all refused to buy it as they were suspicious as to how it came into the possession of the vendor. Then he offered it to the Greek proprietor of a second class restaurant here and they went into partnership and succeeded in disposing of it to a wealthy native here for L.E. 1200. The purchaser went to Cairo with his statue and tried to resell it at a considerable profit to a European connoisseur. This gentleman was astonished to see such a magnificent specimen of statuary in the hands of a native and informed the police, who impounded the statue. The consular authorities at Alexandria were apprised and they at once wired to the Piraeus, whither Pissarakis had gone after securing his share of purchase money and the police there secured him and he is now awaiting trial. Meanwhile the masterpiece is now at the Hellenic Consulate at Cairo.

div.head: PLAGUE AT JEDDAH.
div.p: A telegram from Jeddah reports seven more deaths from plague.
THe departures of pilgrims from that port for Tor have ceased.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Florio-Rubattino S.S. Siracusa, having left Messina eight hours behind time, will not arrive at Alexandria before Sunday evening or Monday morning.

div.head: K.S.C.
THIRD WINTER MEETING.
div.p: Never this season have we had a larger or better meeting than that at yesterday's races at Ghezireh, and as the sun's warmth was most genial most of the ladies had graced the occasion with their prettiest of frocks. Indeed, some of these were a most fragile and summery description, and those who still clung to thicker garments had chosen those of dainty colourings. The racing, too, was of more than ordinary interest, and both the Steerlechare and the Challenge Cup Race excited great enthusiasm and were well worth the watching. It was good, too, to watch the English horses in the Velocity Cup Race excited great enthusiasm and were well worth the watching. It was good, too, to watch the English horses in the Velocity Cup Race, and to note their action, so different to that of the Arabs. VIcomte G. Fontaroe's Caprice came a nasty cropper with Galley during the third race; and though that plucky little jockey did his level est with Lady Meldrum in the Velocity Race, Caprice had to be scratched for the Consolation Race. There was a great deal of interest in the Consolation race, which was a long one giving plenty of scope to both horses and their jockeys. Ghazi and Timsah, both from Ibrahim Bey Cherif's stables, made the pace tremendously at starting; but Jupiter forged well ahead half-way, Doughan, ridden excellently by Jenkins, catching him up later on. Other two, Jupiter and Doughan, made a most excellent finish to the final advantage of the former. Mr. A. Schreiber's luck was with him all the afternoon, for not only did the Rabah come in first the steplechase, but he also won the Challenge Cup; Mulberry, also belonging to Mr. Schreiber, making a good second in the Intter race. The handicapper (who is of course a much abused person, like the wretched referee at football) brought his horses together very successfully. The Pari Mutuel did a great trade, about £3,000 changing hands. The two extrememly handsome Cups presented by Mr. D.K. Reid, for the Club Challenge CUp, and by Mr. Hogg for English horses were exhibited and very much admired.

Amongst those who were present during the course of the afternoon were:- Mr. Machell and Lady Valda Machell, Lord and Lady Lauesborough, Lady Newborough, the Count and Countess von Hollunstein, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Lady Vivian, Sir Williams Garstin, Sir Vincent Corbett, SIr James and Miss Blyth, General and Miss Bullock, Col and Lady Campbell, Mrs. Gordon and her niece, Miss Mitchell Innes and Miss Morrit, Mrs. and Miss Leverich, the Misses York, Capt. and Mrs. Schreiber and Miss Hurley, Mr. and Mrs. Montagu Summers, Mrs. Stanley Bird, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Daleglieh, Mr. and Mrs. Chorlton, Mr. and Mrs. C.H. Moore, Capt. and Mrs. Wilson, Mrs. and Miss Nungovich, Dr. and Mrs. Molan and Miss Moore, Capt and Mrs. Clifford Hall, Col and Mrs. Donegan and Mrs. Twomey, Mr. and Miss Eldy, Capt and Mrs Rome, Capt. and Mrs. Herbert and Miss Gorst, Mr. Curphy, Mr. and Mrs. P Stout, Dr. and Mrs. Phillips and Miss Coxon, Johnson Pasha and Miss JOhnson, Mr. and Mrs. Foaden, Capt. and Mrs Bayley, Dr. Bentley, Mr. Rom, Mrs. and Miss Crofon, Crookshank Pasha and Miss Carey and Miss Fox, Miss McKellar, Mr. and Mrs. Vera Alston, Miss Molloy, Miss Shaw, Mrs. and Miss Bennett, Mrs. Armstrong and Miss de Vahl, Mr. and Mrs. Brunyate, Mr. and Mrs. Hebard, Mr. and Mrs. Tatton Brown, the Misses Davidson, etc, etc.

div.head: UP-RIVER SEASON.
HOTELS STILL VERY FULL.
div.p: The up-river season is at its full height, and the accommodation of the hotels at Luxor is being taxed to its utmost to cope with the demands for rooms. Many well-known faces are to be seen just now. Lord Cromer arrived here last week in his boat with Lady Cromer and their little son also on board. They spent a few days at Luxor then, and stopped again on their return journey, and they were to be seen on more than one occassion in the Winter Palace Hotel, while the little boy was an interested spectator at the Gymkhana on Thursday. Sir. William Garstin and Captain and Lady Valda Machell have also been seen about during the last few days.

Amongst distinguished visitors staying at the Winter Palace this week are the Earl and Countess of Carnarvon, Susan Countess of Malmesbury, Sir Vincent Corbett, Mustapha Pasha Kamel, Sir John Ardagh, the Comte and Comesse de Pourtales and party, Judge Hatton, and Mr. Tabot Kelly and family.

The weekly dances at this hotel are being kept up with much spirit and next Tuesday, the 26th, there is to be a "bal poudre." in place of the usual fancy dress dance. THe tickets are 25 P.T. for gentlemen and 15 P.T. for ladies, and the proceeds are to go to the Luxor Hospital for Natives.

Dr. Theodore Acland, who is staying at the Luxor Hotel, is well known to fame in Egypt, having been sent out by the British Government in 1883 to deal with the cholera epidemic. He was then selected for special service in the Egyptian Army, and became P.M.O. He is now taking a holiday in the country, and must find much that is new to insert him since last he visited it.
Mr. Talbot Kelly, who is now at the winter Palace, has been painting at Assouan, and is also working here for a short time before returning to Cairo for the rest of the season.

The gymkhana on Thursday attracted an unusually large number of spectators. Besides the usual races for natives, the visitors' events comprised a donkey race, a goolah pegging race, and a nomination race.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: M. Cicondicola, Italian Minister at the Ethiopian Court, is expected at Cairo, having definitely left his post. The Italian Charge d'affaires at the Court of the Negus is the Marquis Colli di Felizzano. M. Ciccodicola is on his way to Italy.

Mrs. Cassel and Mrs. Ashely, who have been spending their last few days in Cairo and the Savoy, are leaving to-day with Sir Ernest Cassel for Biarritz. Other late departures from the Savoy include Mr. Heston Armstrong, M.P. Major and Mrs. Wynne, who, with Miss Blythe, are now en route for England.

The Count and Countess A. Bobrinsky and Sir. Thos. R. Dewer are among the late arrivals at the Savoy. Sir Charles Wyndham and Miss Mary Moore have also returned to their old quarters after their trip up-river, and Prince and Princess Livoff, who have also been in Upper Egypt, have likewise returned to the same hotel, as have Baron Bleichroder, Baron Biedermann and their parties.
Mr and Mrs. Francis Allen, Miss Allen, and Miss Gwendolyn Allen arrived at Alexandria this morning by the S.S. Osmanieh on their return from Europe.

The following travelled to Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Thursday: Mr. Spinks, Mr. and Mrs. Bierre, Mrs. J. Innes, Mr. and Mrs. hadur, Mr. Biggart, Mr. and Mrs. Burton, Miss Snarks, Misses Spinks, Mr. Allen, Ibrahim Pasha Racheb, Count Lehndof, Mr. Sacroug, Mr. Raimond, Mr. and Davies, Mr. Andrus and party.

div.head:
WRECK OF THE BERLIN.
EFFORTS AT RESCUE.
DESPAIRING APPEAL FOR HELP.

div.p: The lifeboat continued to make desperate efforts until late in the evening to reach the wreck, on which a few persons were visible, and from which cries were audible. Three times communication was established, but each time the ropes snapped. A board was washed ashore on which a despairing appeal for help was written in copying ink stating that fifteen persons were alive in the smoke-room.
(Reuter).

A lifeboat and a tug made heroic but fuitless efforts throughout the night, in the face of terrific seas and furious snowqualls to reach the wreck of the Berlin. At daybreak some persons were still living and visible on board.
Later.
This afternoon the lifeboats repeated their efforts to reach the wreck, and finally succeeded in throwing lines.
Later.
Eleven persons have been saved: five of the crew, two ladies of the opera chorus, and four gentlemen, including Herr Broderson. (Reuter).
The survivors of the S.S. Berlin, who had taken refuge on some wreckage, have been saved.

div.head:
FURIOUS GALE IN EUROPE.
SHIPPING CASUALITIES.

div.p: A furious gale continues to rage in the western part of the Continent of Europe. A Norwegian three-master has been driven ashore on the coast of Denmark. The crew of 18 men have been drowned. (Reuter).
A German cruiser collided with, and sank, a tug. 5 persons have been drowned. (Reuter).
It is hoped that it will be possible to refloat the Jean Bart. (Havas).

div.head:
THE HOUSE OF LORdS.
LORD NEWTON'S BILL.

div.p: Lord Newton, Conservative, has introduced a bill providing that only Peers who held high office or had been twice elected to the House of Commons should be personally entitled to sit in the House of Lords. The other Peers should elect a fourth of their number to represent them during each parliament. The number of bishops in the House of Lrods should be reduced. (Reuter).
The papers are hostile to the appointments which have been made to the Upper House. (Reuter).

The newspapers remark that the election for the Presidency of the Reichstag, in which the Centre had no say at all, represents a victory for the Conservative and Liberal majority a desired by the Chancellor. (Reuter).
The Government has officially made known that it is prepared to receive the Peace Conference about 1st Juen. (Havas).
Waterloo Cup. Lonspan beat Giembridge. (Reuter).

div.head: MENA HOUSE.
div.p: SUCCESSFUL FANCY DRESS BALL.

It is many seasons since the beautiful dining-hall of Mena House has been utilized for dancing; and one can only hope that the most successful ball held there on Wednesday night may prove the first of many under Mr. Klinger's able management. Busy hands had hung the walls and arches with the flags of many countries, adding welcome touches of colour to the scene and giving a very gala appearance to the occasion. A great number of original and pretty costumes were donned before the dinner hour, many cheery parties assembling to partake of the very excellent menu provided for their delectation. H.R.H. the Prince Bena of Siam, who is staying at the hotel, was a very interested spectator throughout the evening, occupying a table at dinner where he had a full view of all the guests as they entered the ball. The Earl and Countess of Meath were also present at dinner, and the Hon. Mrs. Cubitt was with a party. Dr. Hayward of Port Said also had a party of 6; and a large contingent of 18, from Ghezireh Palace, had chartered a special tram to convey them out in time for dinner. Amongst this contingent were Mrs. and Miss Crofton, Mrs. and Miss Carey, Mrs. Marou, Mrs. Norman Smith, Miss Fox, Messrs. Adams, Boys and Hicks; and there were various others well known in Cairo present.

Many hands make light work. As soon as dinner was finished an army of attendants fell upon the dining hall packing away the tables and chairs, rolling up and carrying away the immense carpet, and giving a final polish to the well-laid floor in an incredibly short space of time, and before ten o'clock the sextett orchestra was in its position and the first strains of music recalled the visitors back to the scene of action. The dances at Mena are always successful; but this one proved even more so than usual, and Mr. and Mrs. Klingler deserve the personal thanks of all who were present for one of the cheeriest entertainments of the season.

Some of the costumes worn were extremely original and well carried out, and three at least deserve special mention. That of Miss Geddes was of white silk most beautifully painted and designed by herself with the frontpieces of well-known pieces of music, et. Indeed she might well have represented the spirit of the waltz, for as she lightly squng round the room to her favourite measure one caught glimpses of her favourite music from skirt and sack and corsage, while her high head decoration carried out the same idea. Mrs. Wentworth Shields had chosen cigarettes as a novel schema of decoration. Many of these were piled upon her powdered hair, fringes of them also appearing on the decoletage and sleeves of her bodice, while the sash draped across her frock bore the legend "Salem Aleikim." Miss Handasyd Dick's decorations of flywhisks was distinctly original and pleasing. A row of these hung round the fulness of the skirt, and another waved like the fashionable paradis above her coiffure, and the remainder of her dress was swathed about and hung with many chains of the white shells and green bends so well known in Egypt. Capt. Trefusis as "Forty Years Hence" had completely veiled his identity beneath a white wig and beard and tired wrinkles across his forehead and about his eyes. His sturdy stick also was necessary to steady his feeble footsteps, though there was little trace of age about him when he joined the dancers. Mirs. Bull made an excellent Turkish lady with scarlet cap crowning her dark hair, and with many particoloured sashes draped about her, and Mr. Bull was very well got up as a syce. Miss Lyon Campbell was not in fancy dress, but her sister was wearing a real old costume of brocade worn over a scarlet skirt and trimmed with beautiful lace, which became her well. Miss James also donned a white wig with her pretty grandmother's dress of pink with a big white fichi; but she also danced with all the abandon of youth in spite of her assumed character. Mr. Blomfield was a wonderful mandarin with shaved forehead, oblique eyebrows and most truly Chinese shoes, and Mr. D. Bennett appeared in the embroidered robes of real Japan. Miss Dumaresq looked most effective in her Tyrolean costume, and Mlle. Gussard was a and very youthful Charlotte Corday. There were two Norwegian peasants, one being Mrs. Maron, who were dressed with absolute attention to deatils. and Miss Fox's pretty Directoire costume was most becoming to her. Miss Crofton, too, looked extremely well in her costume entitled "Monte Carlo, and Miss Carey as Carmen could not have chosen anything to suit her better. Mr. Adams in his glittering Crusader suit excited much attention, and Mr. Triman too was very impressive in his Joseph coat of many colours and his tall white hat. Mr. Heron was in a Russian blouse and furry cap, Dr. Wakeling in the flowing robes of a Bedouin sheikh, Mr. Hicks in a very handsome Eastern toilette, Mr. Wentworth Shields as a chef; while memory fails as to the wearer of a magnificent tunic and turban of gold embroidery, which were perhaps the most handsome garment in the room.

Amongst others noticed during the evening, were Mrs. Lyon Campbell, Mrs. Ludlow, Mrs. Koch, Mrs. James, Mrs. Norman Smith, poudree, Miss Eveline Hodgson, poudree Mrs. Timins, poudree, Miss Felix Brown and Mrs. Rigden.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The S.S. Sicillia left Southampton yesterday with troops on board for Crete Malta and Egypt. The Sicillia will call at Alexandria on the 26th inst. to disembark drafts and details, and will leave the following day.
There are details and drafts on board for most of the suits in Egypt, and 181 noncommissioned officers and men for the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps at Khartoum.

The 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers left Belfast on the afternoon of the 12th inst. for Crete, via Southampton, where it embarked the following day on the S.S. Sicillia. The departure of the battalion from Belfast was marked by extraordinary scenes of enthusiasm, mixed with regret, for this is one of the few Irish stations where the soldier is welcomed for his own sakeand not for what can be made out of him. The battalion was played to the Heysham boat, the S.S. Antrim, by the bands of the Rifle Brigade and 4th Battalion Royal Irish Rifles, whilst thousands of civilians of all classes thronged the streets to give the gallant old 24th a suitable send-off. The scenes were very pathetic in some cases, for many of the rank and file are Belfast men, the regiment having always been looked upon as the North of Ireland one, from its ancient associations. At the boat, the throng was so great that the civil police had to draw their batons to keep back the people. It was an injudicious act, for a Belfast crowd sending off a regiment is not to be trifled with. Fortunately nothing untoward happened, and the Inniskillings steamed down the Lough to the cheers of thousands. At the Queen's Island, where the Atlantic greyhounds are built, the 27th came in for another send off from the thousands of work-men there employed. THe officers accompanying the battalion are- Lieutenant Colonel Davidson, D.S.O., commanding Majors Hickman Hancocks, and Blenuerhassett; Captians Kenny, Mitchell, Crawford, Stewart, Ridings Gordon, and Smyths (adjutant); Lieutenants Manderson, Pike Kirkpatrick, Dunbar, Crofton, Henderson-Scott, Hammond-Smith and Lieutenant and Quartermaster Morris. In the brigade orders of the 11th inst. the following paragraph appears- "Farewell Order- The Brigadier General commanding (Brigadier General Dawson, C.V.O.) wishes to place on record his appreciation of the good conduct of the battalion during the time it has been quartered in Belfast. The good behavior and soldier-like conduct and turn out of the non-commissioned officers and men in the streets reflects great credit on all ranks, and the Brigadier General hopes that the battalion will earn for itself as good a reputation in its new station as it has borne in Bellfast." There was practically no serious "crime" in the battalion for the simple reason that all "undesirables" were at once removed from it when they showed themselves. The old 27th carried away very pleasant memories of their sixteen months in Ireland's commercial capital.

The details of the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers- just gone to Creteand those of the Connaught Rangers, will proceed to Tidworth Camp, Salisbury Plain, on the 19th inst. for attachment to the Provisional Battalion until the return home of their respective 2nd Battalions next trooping season.

After all, the reported action of Lord Charles Beresford in refusing to accept the command of the Channel Fiest until it was in a perfect state for the defence of the waters for which it was brought into existence, did not create the sensation one expected. If the statement be true it is on all fours with Lord Charlie's conduct in naval affairs, for he has previously given an ultimatum to the Government. The country will back the gallant Irishman, for it knows his value, and in any cases the affair is a proper exposure of the miserable thriftness of the administration of all the virtues.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Cotons.

Nous avons sommes ouvent recries contre le systems de la propagation des nouvelles que l'on siat pertinemment etre infondees et nous le ferons encore une fois aujourd'hui. Certes, nous n'avons pas la pretention de corriger ce defaut chez ceux qui ont recours a ce moyen pour influencer le marche, ni ne voulons nous poser en detenseurs des naifs qui se laissent souvent prendre a ce petit jeu; ce role de Don Quichotte ne nous incombe pas! Aussi, si nous revenons sur ce point, ce n'est que pour repeter ce qui a ete deja dit, a savoir que ces trucs sont simplement odieux, car, generalement, ce ne sont que les petitis qui en sont les victimes. On nous repondra par ce pseudoaxiome que la fin justifie les moyens, que d'ailleurs ces choses la passent pour des peches veniels a la Bourse et au'apres tout ceuz qui ne sont pas au courant de la veritable situation du march d'ont qu'a se renseigner avant de se laisser entrainer. Tout cela est bel et bon et nous ne tonsn pas a le discuter, mais est-ce que la partie ne serait pas bien plus noble si, au lieu de transiger avec leur conscience, les manipulateurs des marches se contentaient de profiter d'une fecon loyale des occasions que les circumstances leur offrent parfois?

Pour ne pas avoir l'air de faire un cours de morale que personne ne nous demande, nous nous arretons la dans ces reflextions qui nous ont ete inspirees par les faits de samedi dernier et nous nous contenterons de constrater que c'est tout simplement en telephonant au Caire qu'une combinaison avait ete conclue pour prendre livreaison du mars, que le devouvert sur le mois en question etait enorme et qu'il n'y aurait aucuue emission de titieres, que l'ou est parvenu a chauffer la speculation de la captiale et a l'induire a racheter ete au dela, ce que la veille et l'avent-veille elle avait vendu en contrats mars. Premier resultat obtenu, hausse de 1/8 pour la matinee.

Ces dispositions ayant paru assex chaudes a nos haussiers, la mancelivre a ete continuees lundi, et cette fois elle a eu plein succes, etant donne que dans l'apres midid le cours du mars a finir par atteindre le niveau de 22 tallaris. En attendant, nombre d'interesses de notre place avaient reussi a passer a leurs confreres du Caire leurs paquets de mars, et comme la demande surgie pour ce mois avait reduit le report pour mai a 7/16 de tallri, beaucoup d'arbitragistes en ont profite pour revendre le mars, au transfert duquel ils avaient deja consenti, avec l'idee, bien entendu, de la reprendre par la suite avec des differences baucoup plus sensibles en leur faveur.

Au fond, il faut bien le reconnaitre, le tout etait bien joue, et ceux qui avaient donne dans le panneau a fete baissee, s'en sont bien apercus, mais un peu trop tard! En tous cas, la consequence de leur precipitation a croire tout ce qui leur avait ete raconte, a consiste dans l'elargissement du report de Mars a Mai a 11/16, justifiant de la sorte les calculs qui avaient specule sur cette evantualle. Pour le moment, les nouveaux detendre du Mars luttent dans le secret espoir qu'il n'y aura pas de fieres, mais, comme on peut bien le comprendre, ce n'est la qu'une illusion, car avec l'enorme quantite pour le mois prochain que la speculation s'est mise sur les epaulez, il n'y aurait, pour emptcher les mises a disposition, qu'un report plus large encore que l'actuel et suffisant pour tenter tous les vendeurs, meme les plus avides. Nous convenons qu'avec cela les haussiers n'ameliorent pas leur position, mais, somme toute, et, comme d'habitude, ils gagneront du temps et apres tout l'Imprevu existe toujours.

Malgre la retraite des principaux faisuers, la tenue de Mardi a ete femre, mais la journee de Mercredi et la matinee d'hier ont ete marquees du coin de la fablesse. Toutefois, apres un recul a 21 15/32, il y a eu de nouveau reprise et la cloture de ce soir s'est faite sur la cote de 21 22/32.

Comme on le voit, tout le borit meme pendant la semaine aboutit tout simplement a 1/8 de hausse. Ce n'est pas beaucoup, mais comme les choses recelles, soit la continuation des grosses recettes et la persistance de la filature danse son abstention seraient deux causes de faibles-se, on n'aurait jamais pu s'attendre a meiux. Dans tous le cas, la chose aurait ete difficile, avec cette mance de la filiere. Mars qui nous pend sur la fete et qui pourrait nous valoir un veritable coup de massuer. Reste, il est vrai, la tenue de l'Egyptien et la hausse qui en a ete la consequence; mais est-on bien sur que cette demande si inattendue de ces temps derniers duera longtemps encore et que nous ne courons aucun risque d'assister a une de ces voltefaces qui tres souvent se sont proudited d'une facon inopionee? Bref, nous traversons pour le moment une periode transitoire et aucune tendance marquee ne pourra, se de siner avant que la question du Mars n'ait ete liquidee, ou pour le moins, elucidee.

On se demande quel peut avoir ete la cause du reveil si soudain de Liverpool pour nos cotons. Sur la foides renseignements recueillis, il y a un peu de tout, soit couvertures pour compte d'Alexandrie trouvant plus de convenance a acheter la bas pour liverer, ventes de files que, snas perdre de temps, la filature a tenu a couvrir en disponsible et demande de l'etranger, etc. Tous ces detials importent peu, sauf le premier point, car au fond c'est de la marchandise qui passe en filature. Quant a ce qui est de la premiere eventualite, nous avons deja dit dernierement qu'elle pourrait nous valoir pour la suite une certaine diminuition dans nos exporations.

A ce propos nous relevons qu quelwues personnes ont cru mettre en avant comme une cause de hausse tout refus de la filature anglaise de vendre des viles pour livraisions a date rapprochees. Comme il n'est pas admissible que la consommation sit pris des engage meints sans les courvrir, cela reviendrait a dire, d'apres notre jugeotte, que les chances pour de nouvelles affaires sur la recolte actuelle ne sont pas grandes. S'il y a des besoins d'acheter du disponsible pour les couvrir, d'autant plus que la prochaine recolte est en deport de 2 tallaris! Cela ne semble-t-il pas logique pour le moins.

L'activite a ete grande pendant la semaine pour la recolte actuelle, mais a laisse a desirer pour ce qui regarde la nouvelle.- Il est cependant indeuiable que la tenue du Novembre a ete plus reguiliere, exempte de fluctuations voilentes et que la hausse acquise a pu etre facilment maintenue. Elle consiste en 9/16 de tallaris, la coue du Novembre affichee en cloture de ce soir etant de 19 11/16.

QUant au calme relatif qu s'est fait remarqur, il provient de deux canses, la reserve montree par la filature et le desir chez beaucoup de detentuers de vouloir s'alleger, car certaines positions sont tres surchargees et le prix, apres tout, est trop eleve pour ne pas inspirer un peu de prudence. Par contre, il n'y a presque pas de vendeurs en blanc pour peser sur le marche, ce qui est une chance pour les haussiers.

Da cote de l'Amerique, il n'y a rien de serieux: nous haussons et nous baissons, mais en definitive nous sommes comme les carabiniers toujours en place. Il y a manque de speculation, ce qui contrebalance l'effet de la demande de la part de la falature, sans compter la surrabondance de coton. Tout n'est pas utilisable, et une partie du surplus restera a l'annee prochaine aux finis de malange, mais en attendant le visible supply, qui tieut le record, offre encore suffisamment de choix.

Le marche du disponible n'a pas ete bienactif, mais is finit ferme, avec un hausse de 3/8 pour les Mit Affifi et de 1/4 pour les provenances. Haute-Egypte et cela a la suite de la situatuion des contrats. L'Abassi par contre et le Joannovich sont sans changement.
La demande est moderes pour le spot, mais elle porte un peu sur toutes les qualities.

Les exportations ont ete une veritable surprise cette semaine: on s'attendrait a quelque chose de tres deduct et on a finin par avoir 6,000 Balles en plus de l'annee passee, les chiffres etant de 23,000 contre 17,000. Cela a un peu contribue au soutien.

Pour la semaine prochaine il y aura revanche, ditons pour notre part nous ne saurions faire de pronostics, surtour apres ce qui est arrive ces dernieres semaines. Nous porrons expedier moins que la semaine correspondante en 1906, mais comme total due mols, nous n'aurons pas la reduction pre-conisee de 20% sur Fevrier 1906. Si la chose atteint 15% environ ce sera encore beau.

Comme mouvement de la recolte, nous constatons que les recettes jusqu'ici sont de 6,315,000 cantars, que les exportations sont de 82.000 balles superieures a l'annee derniere a la meme date et que finalement le stock est de 1.807.000, contre 1.435.000 cantars.
Liverpool, tres actif pour les egyptiens disponsibles, nous signale pour la semaine une hausse de 1/4 pour le spot et de 29/64 pour le Mars qui ont respectivement fini a 11 1/8 et 11 5/64.

Quant aux americains, la cloture du spot a 6.03, celle du Mars-Avril a 5.65 et celle du Juillet-Aout a 5.60, nous montrent qu'en tout et pour tout il n'y a que deux points de hausse et sur la derniere echeance seulement.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: satisfaissantes, les recettes ont ete insufficantes pour les gros besoins de l'exportation, et c'est a cette circumstance qu'il faut attribuer la fermete des cours et leur avance a P.T. 76 1/2, soit P.T. 1 1/2, au-dessurs de vendredi dernier.
Les embarquements de la semaine prochaine seront aussi assex importants pour maintenir les prix sauf, bien entendu, changements subits du dehors dans la situation de l'article.

Pour le moment, Hull reste ferme, quoi-que peu actif, mais si la situation des Huiles en Amerique ne se modifie pas a bref delai, il y aura reveil dans la demande d'ici quelque temps Ce sont les bonnes huiles qui sont rares et malgre la convenance des graines de Bombsy, on aura toujours recours aux graines d'Egypt a cet effet. La derniere cote est de 7 7/6 pounds pour le prompt.
En contrats, peu d'affaires; mais grande fermete et comme cloture definitive de la semaine P.T. 1 1/4 de hausse, le Fevrier-Mars ayant fini a P.T. 77 3/4.
La nouvelle recolte ne donne lieu qu'a de rares affaires. Le prix de debut est trop eleve et arrete tout elan chez la speculation. Les 3 mois ont cloture a P.T. 69 35/40.

div.head: BOURSE DU CAIRE
div.p: Le Caire, le 22 Fevrier 1907.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Le marche de Londres a ete cette semanie franchement mauvais. Non-seulement le taux prive d'escompte a hausse de 1/8 a 4 7/8% et le Consolide a baisse d'une demi-livre a 86 5/8, mais encore les valeurs egyptiennes sans exception ont subi une depreciation plus ou moins notable: 1/8 pour la Daira a 17 3/8, 1/4 pour l'Agricole et la Delta Light a 9 3/4 et 11 1/2 et 1/2 pour la National Bank a 27 7/8. La reserve de la Banque est de plus tombee de 50 1/4 a 48 1/8% soit plus de 2% de perte.

A Paris, si la Rente Francaise 3% a beneficie d'une legere reprise de 10 centimes a 95.50, les valeurs egyptiennes ont montre, par contre, une toute aussi mauvaise tenue qu'on Angleterre: le Credit Foncier Egyptien est tombe a 755; il est vrai qu'il faut tenicompte du coupon detache nagnere, mais ce motif n'existe pas pour le Credit Franco-Egyptien qui a neanmoins perdu 5 fr. a 158; la Land Bank a egalement flechi a 228.

Pour notre place la semaine qui vient de s'ecoulera ete la plus terne que nous ayions eue a analyser depuis la morte saison, c'est-a-dire depuis le mois d'sout. En titres de placement, la nullite a ete complete; sur les valeurs meme legeres et de pure speculation les affaires au comptant n'ont en aucune importance; tout a ete pour fin et encore les transactions ont-elles ete forcement limitees par suite du malaise croissant qui pere sur notre marche. Les operations en nouvelles emissions se sont elles-memes rareifiees au point de rendre icomprehensible la hate que mettent les lanceurs d'affaires a nous doter de leurs brillantes cominaisons. Des samedi, la position generale est aux ventes, amis sans succes, faute de contrepartie. Meme situation lundi. Le lendemain la nullite persiste pour le comptant; quelques transactions s'effectuent pour fin, de preference sur les nouvelles emissions pour lesquelles il n'y a rien a verser. Mercredi la situation ne fait qu'empirer; on commence a reporter pour fins mars: quelques-uns, trop surcharges, cherchent a s'alleger d'une partie de leur stock, ce qui entraine une baisse generale. Les deux dernieres seances, hier et aujourd'hui, ont les memes caracteristiques; debut en pleine debacle pour reprendre un peu vers la fin, mais cloturer en somme a un niveau generalement inferieur a celui de la veille.
Sur ne soixantaine de valeurs inscrites a la cote officielle de notre bourse, trente et une sont en baisse, cinq seulement en hausse et les autres demeurent stationnaires.

Les fluctuations les plus sensibles sont: a la hausse, la Nile Land qui beneficie d'une livre et demie d'avance a 24; et a la baisse, la National Bank qui perd 1/4 a 27 3/4, les Privilegiees Tramways 5 fr. a 192, la Behera 1 livre a 39, la Cassa di Sconto 4 fr. 50 l'ancienne a 271 1/2 et 6 fr. la nouvelle a 264. La Ramleh, la Delta Light, la Deferred Delta, le Comptoir, l'Union Fonciere, les Cotton Ginners, et les Constructions reculent respectivement de 1/8. L'Agricole perd 3/32 a 9 3/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire 2 fr.,la Salt and Soda 6 pence, les Lots Turcs 1 fr. la Delta Land 1/16, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail 1 shelling, l'Investment 1/16, les Estates 3,32, les Splendid Hotels 1/16, le Cheikh Fadl 1 fr., le Banco di Roma 2 fr., le Credit Franco-Egyptien 1/16, la Banque d'Orient 0. fr. 75, l'Aboukir 6 pence, l'Allotment 1/16 et la Port Said Salt 1 shelling 3 pence; par contre, la Banque d'Athenes reprend de 2 fr. a 134 1/2, les Nungovich et les Building Lands de 1/8 a 29 1/8 et 5 15/16, et la Levant du 1/16 a 7/8.

Les valeurs nouvelles et les emissions en cours ne sont guere plus favorisees: les Ritz Hotels flechissent de 2 3/16 a 1 29/32, la Levico de 1 5/16 a 1 1/4, l'Arditi de 1 3/8 a 1 1/4; la Lunghis cloture a 1 1/4 et l'United a 1 7/32. La Karam est negligee au dessous du pair, ainsi d'ailleurs que la Banque d'Escompte et de Reports.

L'assemblee generale des actionnaires de la Nile Land and Agricultural Company a ete tenue lundi, 18 courant, au siege social a Alexandrie. Il a ete decide de distribuer un dividende de 5% soit 25 P.T. par action, payable a partir du 4 du mois prochain a l'Anglo Egyptian Bank. Il ressort du rapport du conseil d'administration, qui sera publie ces jours-ci que sur une etendue de terrain de 285,000 metres carres environ, la societe en a rovendu 144,000 pour une somme de 1.300.000 L.E. environ. Le prix global d'achat etant de 1.500.000 L.E., on voit que la vente des 135.000 metres qui restent constituera un benefice presque net. On concoit dans ces conditions la hausse presque ininterrompue du titre qui a cette semaine atteint 24 livres, en depit de la baisse generale. De tels resultats font evidemment honneur au conseil d'administration et la satisfaction des actionnaires dont le capital s'accroit de facon prodigiuse est le plus bel eloge qu'on puisse faire de leur gestion.

Il est question depuis quelques temps de l'absorption des Nungovich Hotels par les Estates. Ceux-ci ont deja achete le Savoy Hotel et sont en pourparlers pour l'acquisition du Grand Continental au prix de 800,000 livres.
On nous informe qu'un dividende de 1 shelling, equivalant au 20% du capital, appele, sera declare le 28 courant a l'assemblee generale de l'Egyptian Investment and Agency qui sera tenue a Londres.

Au nombre des nouvelles emissions qui ont eu lieu cette semaine, signalons celles de la Nile Transport Co., de la Levico et de la Banque d'Escompte et de reports. Lundi prochain sera ouverte la souscription a la Bourse and Banking (Arditi). La succes de cette derniere est d'ores et deja assure, grace a la prime de 1/4 dont jouit cette valeur.

A l'assemblee de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. tenue samedi par les ad-ministrateurs il a ete decide de retablir avec la Delta Light les rapports qui avaient ete rompus. La Delta Land se trouve donc de nouveau vis-a-vis de la Delta Light dans la meme situation que lors de sa creation. L'administration, qui avait donne lieu a d'innombrables tiraillements entre Londres et le Caire au grand detriment des interests sociaux, a ete centralisee en Egypte, Le conseil de Londres a demissionne et un conseil local a ete elu qui offre toutes les garanties de bonne gestion: M.M.P.W. Carver, Maurice Cattani Bey, Capt. A. Adams, R.E. Jacques de Menasce et J.W. Williamson. Un membre de la maison Suares du Caire sera egalement adjoint conseil, des que certains pourparlers auront abouti. Une assemblee generale des actionnaires va etre incessamment tenue a Londres pour ratifier ces resolutions.

div.head: Saved From Threatened Catarrh of the Lungs By Taking Pe-ru-na!
div.p: Mrs Mois Parizeau, Ste. Julie de Vercheres, P.W., Canada, writes:
"I hardly know how to thank you for the good Peruna has done me."
"I suffered five years with the pain in the stomach. About a year ago it became so bad I could hardly bear it."
"I coughed day and night and grew weaker and weaker. The pains extended through my body and I also had difficulty breathing, which made me cough. Everyone thought I had consumption."
"My husband heard of Peruna and bought five bottles."
"This treatement virtually cured me and now I recommend Peruna to everyone who is suffering."
"I thank Dr. Hartman for this excellent remedy."
--- MRS. MOIS PARIZEAU
A NEGLECTED cold is generally the first cause of catarrh.

Women are especially liable to colds. These colds occur more frequently during the wet, sloppy weather of winter and spring than any other time of the year. Often they are not considered serious and so are allowed to run on, or they are treated in such a way as to only palliate the symptoms, while the cold becomes more deep-seated and the patient finally awakens to the fact that she has a well-developed case of catarrh.

By reason of their delicate structure, the lungs are frequently the seat of a cold, especially if there is the slightest weakness of the organs. The treatment of catarrh of the lungs is also more difficult and discouraging than catarrh of any other organ of the body.
It would be wise, therefore, to guard against it by every precaution possible.
Peruna has been found the most reliable of all remedies for coughs, colds, and catarrh, by reason of the fact that it foes at once to the very seat of the trouble.

It searches out every crevice, every duct of the body. It quickens and equalizes the circulation of blood, thus relieving the congested mucous membranes. It exercises a healing and soothing effect upon the mucous membranes no matter whether they are the exposed membranes of the head and throat, or whether they line the remotest cells of the lungs.
A word to the wise woman is sufficient. Take Peruna at the first appearance of a cold.
Those desiring special instructions regarding the use of Peruna, should address Dr. S.B. Hartman, President of The Hartman Sanitarium, Colombus, O.

For special directions everyone should read "The Ills of Life," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings.
Those wishing direct correspondence with Dr. Hartman and can wait the necessary delay in receiving a reply should address Dr. S.B. Hartman, Columbus, Ohio, U.S.A.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie)

Les nouvelles emissions ont ete generalement negligees ce matin au profit des anciennes valeurs. On a traite principalment Les Nungovich, la Delta Land, la Nile Land, les Estates, le Comptoir, la Building Lands et le Credit Franco-Egyptien. La cloture indique cependant une nouvelle depression de la cote, bien qu'il y ait eu vers la fin une reprise partielle. Le debut de la seance avait ete, en effet, franchement mauvais.

En hausse il faut signaler les Nungovich Hotels beneficient d'une demilivre a 29 5/8, la Delta Land de 1/8 a 4 5/16, les Estates de 1/32 a 2 1/2, l'Union Fonciere de 3/16 a 6 3/16 et l'Agricole de 1/16 a 9 13/16.

Par contre, les Priviligiess Tramways flechissent a 190, la Filature a 21/32 vendeurs, la Khedivial Mail a 4 5/8, l'Urbaine a 7 5/16 l'ancienne et 6 13/16 la nouvelle, la Building Lands a 5 7/8 et l'Allotment a 3 1/4.

La tendance est un peu meilleure. Sans vouloir prejuger de cette amelioration, que nous annoncions depuis deux ou trois jours, on est oblige de reconnaitre que la cote a attteint pour les valuers de placement un niveau de depreciation qu'il sera difficile de depasser, en mettant les choses au pire, ce qui n'est pas le cas.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres a ete eleve hier de 1/8 a 4 7/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais s'est maintenu a 86 5/8, de meme que l'Unifee a 102 3/4. La National Bank a perdu 1/4 a 27 7/8 et l'Agricole 1/8 a 9 3/4. La Daira est restee invariee a 17 3/8 ainsi que la Delta Light a 11 1/2.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a retrograde de 3 francs a 756 et la Banque d'Athenes de 1 franc a 134.

Influence, d'une part, par les circunstances d'ordre local que nous avons suffisamment exposees a cette place et, d'autre part, par la tenue de moins en moins, favorable des Bourses de Londres et de Paris, notre marche des valeurs continue a montrer de mauvaises dispositions. La seance de ve matin a ette aussi peu satisfaisante que celle d'hier et il y a encore a enregistrer des moins-vales sur un grand nombre de titres de la cote. Il faut decidement, sauf cas imprevu, renoncer a voir une reprise stable, sinou une amelioration, se produire avant que la situation se soit eclaircie a la suite de la liquidation de fin de mois. Toutefois il serait en meme temps temeraire de s'attendre a une accentuation notable de la depression, la baisse paraissant avoir plus ou moins dit son dernier mot, specialement sur les bonnes valeurs, dont les cours deviennent de plus en plus tentants pour le placement aussi bien que pour la speculation.

Dans le compatiment des Banques, la National, fortement offerte, a encore faibli a 27 3/4-13/16. L'Agricole a molli a 9 3/4 13/16. La Cassa di Sconto s'est tenue a 273 74. La Banque d'Abyssinie s'est aloudie a 5 1/4.
Le Credit Foncier a ete delaisse a 755; sa part defendateur a ete cotee 930, ex-coupon. La Behera flechi a 39. La Nile Land a avance a 23 3/4.

Les Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux se sont mainteneues en cloture a 8 3/4; leur part de fondateur a ete ramenes a 202. L'Epargue Immobiliere est restee a 3; sa part a termine a 184. L'Express Nile a flechi a 5; sa part a cloture a 240.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont decliue a 278 et les Ciments a 51. Les Automobilies sont emontees a 9 1/2-9/16.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelieres, les Nungovich ont ete soutenus a 29 1/8. Les Egyptian ont recule a 12 1/8. Les Excelsior ont regagne 1/2 sur la nouvelle que la Societe a recu une nouvelle offre pour son terrain du square Soliman-Pacha. La part National Hotel s'est raffermie a 67.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land est restes a 4 1/8. Les Estates ont ete mieux tenus a 2 1/2, de meme que les New Egyptian 29 sh. 3. Les Cotton Mills sont tombes a 5 sh.
Nous extrayons d'une correspondence de Londres en date du 15 Fevrier, le passage suivant.

"La position de la Banque d'Angleterre au fortifie de plus en plus et ou s'attend a une prochaine diminution du taux de l'escompte officiel. Cette eventualite se serait deja pro-duite, n'etaient les inquiedtudes determinees car l'etat du marche de New York et la perspective d'un nouvel emprunt bresilien. L'argent a ete plus facile cette semaine pour les reports fin Fevrier; on a traite eu general 1/2 pour cent de moins que pour la liquidation precedente.

"Les affaires en valeurs egyptiennes ont ete restreintes au Stock Exchange et la tendance assez faible. Mais on s'attend generealement a une reprise vers la fin du mois ou dans les premiers jours de Mars, specialemtn sur la National Bank, l'Agricole et la Delta Land."

L'assemblee generale ordinarie de la New Egyptian Co. sera tenue a Londres le 8 Mars prochain. A l'ordre du jour: rapport du conseil d'administration, presentation des comptes et fixation du dividende pour l'exercise ecoule.
On s'attend generalement a ce que ce dividende soit de 2 sh 6 a 3 sh. par action.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Societe Anonyme de Wadi Kom-Ombo sont informes que, par deliberation de l'assemblee generale extraordinaire du 2 Fevrier courant, le captial social, qui etait de 60,000 pounds, represente par 150,000 actions de 4 chacuns, a ete porte a 1,000,000 par la creation de 100,000 actions nouvelles de 4, dont la sousciption au pair est reservee aux porteurs actuels. Ceuz-ci ont, en consequence, le droit de souscrire a deux actions nouvelles pour trois anciennes. Ce droit devra etre exerce, a la National Bank of Egypt, d'ici au 2 Avril prochain au plus tard.

div.head: The Upper Egypt Hotels Company.
div.p: AVIS

MM les Actionnaires possesseurs de certificate provisoires d'actions numerotes commenci-de sous, sont pries d'effectuer sans retard les versement du sur ces actions, plus l'interet de 7% l'an, a partir de l'echeance de ces versements, a la National Bank of Egypt au Caire.

En vertu de l'Art. 7 des Status de la Sociere, celle-ci fera proceder, un mois apres la publication des numeros des titres en retard, soit des le 25 Mars 1907, a la vente de ces actions pour le compte et aux risques et perils des retardataires.

This Prospectus has been duly filed with the Registrar of JOINT STOCK COMPANIES.

The Issue is being made simultaneously in London and Egypt. The Subscription list will be opened and closed at Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, at London, Cairo and Alexandria, on the 25th day of February, 1907
Bourse Banking Company of Egypt, Limited.
(Incorporated under the Companies' Acts, 1860 to 1900).
Divided into 120,000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each, and 5,000 Deferred Shares of £1 each.

The profits of the Company made during the financial year or other period comprised in the accounts submitted to the Ordinary General Meeting in each year with any profits carried forward from past years shall be applicable in order of priority and manner following:-

(1) 10% of such profits shall be carried to a special reserve fund to be established pursuant to clause 134 hereof so that whenevere such special reserve fund shall amount to 50% of the nominal capital of the Company for the time being issued the Company in General Meeting may suspend or diminish the setting aside of any further sums to such reserve fund.
(2) The balance shall be applied to the payment of a (non cumulative) dividend for such period at the rate of 6% per annum on the capital paid up on the ordinary shares.
(3) A sum equal to 7% of the remainder shall be paid by way of remuneration to the Directors pursuant to clause 95 hereof.

(4) Of the surplus 60% shall be applicable to the payment of a further dividend on the capital paid up or credited as paid up on the ordinary shares or may be carried to reserve or otherwisee dealt with as the Company is general meeting determines, and 40% shall be divided rateably among the holders of the deferred shares.

In the event of the Company's liquidation the surplus assets after repayment of the capital to the holders of first, the ordinary shares, and secondly, the deferred shares, shall be divided as to 60% amongst the holders of the ordinary shares and as to 40% amongst the holders of the deferred shares in proportion to the amount paid up or credited as paid up on the shares respectively.
The whole of the capital is now being issued and the Directors offer to the public for subscription et par 83,500 Ordinary shares payable as follows:-
Share Warrants to bearer will be issued to original subscribers if required free of duty, after the shares are fully paid.
Directors

row.cell: EUGENE NAHMAN, Alexandria, Egypt, Managing Director of the Societe Generale d'Electricite et de Mecanique.

Secretary and Registered Offices.

Manager and Secretary at Alexandria.
HENRI FOULDE (late Manager of the National Bank of Egypt at Port Said).
Offices for Egypt.
12, Rue Mahmoud Pasha el Falaki.
PROSPECTUS

This Company has been formed for the objects set out in the Company's Memorandum of Association and in particular for the carrying on of the business of stock, share, and produce brokers and the undertaking of Exchange, Bourse, Banking, Financial and Commercial operations and transactions of all kinds.

The Company has secured the co-operation of Messrs. Jacques Arditi and Alber Arditi, who are both well known and much respected in Egypt, where they have carried or business for many years past as stock share and produce brokers under the name of "Arditi & Co." They have agreed to act as Managing Directors for the term of ten years and the Compay will therefore not only have the advantage of their wide experience in financial affairs but should reap the benefit of their valuable connection and clientele.
The Company proposes to take steps to commence business at Alexandria and Cairo immediately it is entitled to do so after the first general allotment of shares.
The Articles of Association contain the following provisions:-
85. The qualifications of a Director shall be the holding of 500 Ordinary Shares in the Company.

95. The Directors shall be entitled to receive by way of remuneration for each financial year or other period comprised in the accounts submitted to an Ordinary General Meeting, a sum equal to 7% upon the amount of the profits (if any) remaining after 10% of the profits has been carried to the Special Reserve Fund, pursuant to clause 125 hereof and the preferntial dividend at the rate of 6% per annum has been declared on the ordinary shares. The said remuneration shall be divided among the Directors in such proportions and manner as they may determine and in default of such determination among them equally. The Company in general meeting may at any time or from time to time vote to the Directors or any of them such additional remuneration as may be thought proper, and such remuneration may be by way of a fixed sum or by way of a percentage on profits or otherwise as may be determined. Provided that a majority of the Directors may by resolution reduce the amount or waive or postpone the payment of their remuneration as may be thought proper, and such remuneration may be by way of a fixed some or by way of a percentage on profits or otherwise as may be determined. Provided that a majority of the Directors may by resolution reduce the amount or waive or postpone the payment of their remuneration or any part thereof and any such resolution shall bind the minority. An alternative Director appointed under clause 89 hereof shall not as such be entitled to any remuneration.

96. Any Director may be employed by or hold any office of profit under the Company except that of Auditor of the Company, and may act either personally or as member of a firm for, or render any professional service to the Company, and may receive remuneration from the Company for so doing in addition to any remuneration payable to him as Director. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra services or to make any special exertions in going or residing out of Egypt or in negotiating or carrying into effect any contract or arrangement by the Company or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, or act as trustee for the Company or its debenture holders, and shall do so, the Company may remunerate such Director either by a fixed sum of percentage of profits, or otherwise, as may be determined by the Director, and such remuneration may be either in addition to, or in substitution for his remuneration above provided. If any Director shall be appointed to represent the Company as a Director of any subsidiary or other company in which the Company shall be interested, he shall, unless otherwise agreed, be entitled to retain the remuneration attaching to such Directorship for his own use.

102. The Directors may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without limitation as to the period for which he is to hold office, and may, subject to any contract between any such Managing Director or Managing Directors and the Company from time to time remove or dismiss him from office, and appoint another in his place.

103. In the case of any vacancy in the office of Managing Director or Managing Directors, the Directors may either fill up the office by the appointment of some other of the Directors, or may discontinue such office, as they may think fit.

104. The remuneration of a Managing Director or Managing Directors subject to any Agreement between him and the Company, shall be fixed by the Directors, and may be by way of salary, commission, percentage, or participation in profits, or by any or all of these modes.
The Directors have subscribed the Company's Memorandum of Association for 31,800 Ordinary Shares and the whole of the Deferred Shares in the following proportions:-
The amount fixed by the Articles as the minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 40 per cent of the shares offered for subscriptions.
The preliminary expenses of the Company are estimated at L.E. 2,000.
By the Articles of Association the capital of the Company can be increased to £500,000 by a single resolution of the Board of Directors.

The Company has entered into two contracts both dated the 19th day of February 1907, the one with Mr. Jacques Arditi providing for his appointment as a Managing Director of the Company for 10 years at a salary of £2,000, the other with Mr. Albert Arditi likewise providing for his appointment as a Managing Director for the same period and salary.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association which forms part of this prospectus is endorsed hereon.
Applications for shares should bemade on the accompanying form, and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on, application to the Company's Bankers.

If no allotment is made the application money will be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for, the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the applicant.
Failure to pay any instalment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.

The above mentioned contracts or copies thereof, together with a print of the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association, may be inspected at the offices of the Company in London, Alexandria, and its offices at Rue Shawarby Pacha at Cairo, during usual business hours at any time before the closing of the subscription list.
Copies of the Prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the said offices of the Company, or from the Bankers.
Dated this 23rd day of February 1907.

div.head: Khedivial Mail Line
div.p: The new 18-knot twin crew S.S. "Osmanieh," leaving Alexandria on February 28th, March 14th and 28th, and April llth, will follow a special fast itinerary, reaching Piraeus (Athens) in 30 hours, Smyrna in 47 hours, and Constantinople in 74 h hours, in connection with the Oriental Railways daily express service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris and London.
Special arrangements will be made for part of the 7.30 am. Express train from Cairo to run direct alongside.

This vessel is most luxuriously appointed, with accommodation (mostly in 2-berth cabins on deck) for 149 first class amidships and 70 second class alt. Her public saloons are exceptionally spacious and attractive, and she is also fitted with 8 large cabines de luxe on the spar deck, and an "Imperial" private suite on the promenade deck comprising sitting-room, lounge, bedroom, 2 cabins, bath room, lavatory, etc., with private promenade deck above.
Photograph of the vessel is on view at Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt), Ltd, and at Hamburg- American Raise-Bureau, Cairo. 29594 15A 1

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier de L'EGYTPIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplement Commercial et Financier de l'"Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de facon a pouvoir etre expendie par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues completes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs; les dernieres statistiques jusqu'a la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Associationi, etc, etc.
L'abonnement pour une annee en Egypte coute 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pou etranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
